===Anglican Province of the Southern Cone of America=== {{Main|Anglican Province of the Southern Cone}} Archbishop [[Gregory James Venables|Gregory Venables]] has also been strongly critical of homosexuality. Bishops in his province criticised the Windsor Report for failing to call liberal churches to repentance. The province has declared itself in "impaired communion" with ECUSA, but continues to maintain full communion with opponents of the Robinson consecration.<ref>Anglican Communion News Service, 12 January 2004. [http://www.anglicancommunion.org/acns/articles/37/25/acns3735.cfm Statement from the Province of the Southern Cone]. Retrieved 22 March 2007.</ref> Venables has authorised dioceses within his province to provide episcopal oversight to United States churches that have left ECUSA.
In December 2007, the convention of the [[Episcopal Diocese of San Joaquin]], an [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]] diocese in [[Central Valley (California)|central]] [[California]], voted to leave the ECUSA and joined the [[Anglican Church of South America|Province of the Southern Cone]] as the [[Anglican Diocese of San Joaquin]]. A minority of the [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal]] Diocese remained in the ECUSA. In October 2008, a majority of the convention of the [[Episcopal Diocese of Pittsburgh]] voted to leave ECUSA and affiliate with the [[Anglican Church of South America|Southern Cone]], resulting in [[Anglican Diocese of Pittsburgh|one body affiliated with the Southern Cone]] and [[Episcopal Diocese of Pittsburgh (Episcopal Church)|a second body remaining within ECUSA]]. The following month, the conventions of two more US dioceses—the [[Diocese of Quincy (Southern Cone)|Diocese of Quincy]] in [[Illinois]] and the [[Diocese of Fort Worth (Southern Cone)|Diocese of Fort Worth]] in [[Texas]]—voted to leave ECUSA and affiliate with the Southern Cone. All were subsequently absorbed into the new [[Anglican Church in North America]].
However, some Anglican representatives from the Diocese of Uruguay expressed their support for the inclusion of same-sex couples.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lr21.com.uy/comunidad/112756-curas-uruguayos-se-reconocen-gay-a-pesar-de-mantenerse-celibes|title=Curas uruguayos se reconocen gay a pesar de mantenerse célibes|website=LARED21|language=es-ES|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref>
===Episcopal Anglican Church of Brazil=== {{Main|Igreja Episcopal Anglicana do Brasil }} The [[Anglican Episcopal Church of Brazil]] is characterised by its [[progressive Christianity|progressive]] [[Theology|theological]] views on homosexuality. After the 1998 [[Lambeth]] Conference, the Anglican Church in Brazil decided to promote two national forums on [[human sexuality]], both held in [[Rio de Janeiro]]. Its decisions guided the policy. According to the final document, the consensus of the Brazilian Church is that [[human sexuality]] is a gift from [[God]], and it should be experienced in peace, freedom, love and respect. The Church has approved of the ordination of openly gay priests and has offered blessing services for same-sex marriages.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://guiame.com.br/gospel/mundo-cristao/anglicanos-dividem-opinioes-sobre-homossexualidade.html|title=Anglicanos dividem opiniões sobre homossexualidade, Notícias Gospel|last=Guiame|website=Guiame|language=pt-BR|access-date=2016-04-13}}</ref> It is understood that the [[Christianity|Church]] should respect the privacy of its members and [[clergy]]. Any kind of public exposure of someone's [[sexual orientation]] (as a pre-requisite to be a member or take part of any ministry) violates this privacy. Because of that progressive position, the [[Bishop]] of the Diocese of Recife, still strongly [[Evangelicalism|Evangelical]], Robinson Cavalcanti, declared Recife to be independent of the [[Anglican Episcopal Church of Brazil|Church of Brazil]], an action that resulted in his being deposed as a bishop by the [[Ecclesiastical Tribunal]].<ref>D. Orlando Santos de Oliveira, 17 June 2005. [http://www.rci.rutgers.edu/~lcrew/dojustice/j311b.html Canonical Trial # 001/2005 of Bishop Edward Robinson de Barros Cavalcanti]. Retrieved 22 July 2007.</ref> Among his main reasons, he pointed out that the Brazilian Church was sympathetic to the ordination of [[Gene Robinson]], as well as the ordination of all [[LGBT]] people. This split the Diocese of Recife in two: one part loyal to Bishop Orlando Santos de Oliveira, primate of the [[Anglican Episcopal Church of Brazil]], and currently coordinated by Bishop Sebastião Gameleira, and the other, under Cavalcanti's leadership, tied to the [[Anglican Church of the Southern Cone of the Americas|Anglican Church of the Southern Cone]].
In 2016, the presiding bishop convened an Extraordinary Synod to discuss adding same-sex marriage to the marriage canon; the proposal was not approved, but it was considered during General Synod in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sn.ieab.org.br/2016/06/30/primaz-convoca-gt-sobre-genero-sexualidades-e-direitos/|title=Primaz convoca GT sobre Gênero, Sexualidades e Direitos « SNIEAB|access-date=2016-07-12}}</ref> On June 1, 2018, the General Synod voted to change the marriage canon to include same-sex couples.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://anglican.ink/article/ieab-synod-adopts-aame-sex-marriage-canon|title=IEAB synod adopts same-sex marriage canon|date=2018-06-01|work=Anglican Ink 2018 ©|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en}}</ref>
===Anglican Church of Canada=== {{Main|Homosexuality and the Anglican Church of Canada}}
[[Sexual orientation]] and the [[Anglican Church of Canada]] exist within a strictly Canadian context. In the secular context, Canadian law underwent a profound change in regards to homosexuality. The last same-sex attracted person to be sent to prison indefinitely as a "dangerous sex offender" was in 1967.<ref name=cbch>[http://www.cbc.ca/news/background/samesexrights/timeline_canada.html In Depth Same-sex rights Canada timeline]</ref> In 1969, the [[Canadian parliament]] passed amendments of the Criminal Code, decriminalising homosexuality in [[Canada]].<ref name=cbch/> On 20 July 1971, the last gay man criminally convicted because of his [[sexual orientation]] was released from prison.<ref name=cbch/> A series of judicial rulings beginning in 2003 legalised [[same-sex marriage in Canada|same-sex marriage]] in the majority of Canada's provinces, and on 20 July 2005, the [[Canadian government]] extended the new definition nationwide by statute.<ref name=cbch/>
Currently ten [[Anglicanism|Anglican]] [[diocese]]s ([[Anglican Diocese of Edmonton|Edmonton]], [[Diocese of Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island|Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island]], [[Diocese of Rupert's Land|Rupert’s Land]], [[Anglican Diocese of Ottawa|Ottawa]], Vancouver-based [[Anglican Diocese of New Westminster|New Westminster]], [[Anglican Diocese of Toronto|Toronto]], London-based [[Diocese of Huron|Huron]], Hamilton-based [[Diocese of Niagara|Niagara]], [[Anglican Diocese of Montreal|Montreal]], and Victoria-based [[Diocese of British Columbia|British Columbia]]) allow the blessing and marriage of same-sex couples. The [[Anglican Parishes of the Central Interior]] (formerly the [[Diocese of Cariboo]]) also permit such [[rite]]s.<ref name=firstcan>{{cite web|url=http://www.anglicanjournal.com/nc/other/news-items/c/sliders/article/same-sex-blessings-available-in-ruperts-land-11301//abp/141.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130102041203/http://www.anglicanjournal.com/nc/other/news-items/c/sliders/article/same-sex-blessings-available-in-ruperts-land-11301//abp/141.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-01-02|title=Same-sex blessings available in Rupert’s Land|work=anglicanjournal.com}}</ref>
On 30 September 2012, the [[Anglican Diocese of Saskatoon|Bishop of Saskatoon]] ordained as deacon a person civilly [[Marriage|married]] to a person of the same sex.<ref name=secondcan>[http://www.anglicanessentials.ca/wordpress/index.php/2012/11/01/statement-from-the-ruperts-land-house-of-bishops/#comments statement from the Rupert's Land Province house of bishops on the ordination of a gay man] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140119053031/http://www.anglicanessentials.ca/wordpress/index.php/2012/11/01/statement-from-the-ruperts-land-house-of-bishops/ |date=19 January 2014 }}</ref>
At the General Synod on July 6, 2013, the [[Anglican Church of Canada|Anglican Church Of Canada]] made the decision to vote on the issue of same-sex marriage at the following synod in 2016. At the General Synod in 2016, a motion to change the marriage canon to include same-sex marriage received the necessary 2/3 majority and was approved; it will receive a second reading in 2019.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/toronto/god-did-not-create-another-adam-anglicans-vote-down-same-sex-marriage/article30880914/|title=Anglicans pass same-sex marriage resolution after vote error discovered|access-date=2016-07-12}}</ref> Following the General Synod, the Dioceses of Niagara and Ottawa decided to allow legal same-sex marriages as a local option.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.anglicanjournal.com/articles/niagara-ottawa-to-offer-same-sex-marriages-toronto-to-consider|title=Niagara, Ottawa to offer same-sex marriages; Toronto to consider|website=www.anglicanjournal.com|access-date=2016-07-12}}</ref> Also in 2016, the [[Anglican Diocese of Toronto|Diocese of Toronto]] elected with [[Kevin Robertson (bishop)|Kevin Robertson]], for the first time, an openly gay and partnered person to be a bishop.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.toronto.anglican.ca/2016/09/17/diocese-elects-three-new-suffragan-bishops/|title=Diocese elects three new suffragan bishops|website=The Diocese of Toronto|access-date=2016-09-19}}</ref>
===Episcopal Church in the United States of America=== {{Main|Episcopal Church (United States)}} {{See also|Ellen Barrett}} In 2003, [[Episcopal Church (United States)|ECUSA]] became the first [[Anglicanism|Anglican]] province to ordain an openly gay priest in a same-sex relationship as a bishop; however, the [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]]'s stance on [[LGBT]] matters had been debated for decades. In 1976, the Church's [[General Convention of the Episcopal Church in the United States of America|General Convention]] passed a resolution stating: "It is the sense of this General Convention that homosexual persons are children of God who have a full and equal claim with all other persons upon the love acceptance, and pastoral concern and care of the Church."<ref>The Archives of the Episcopal Church, [http://www.episcopalarchives.org/cgi-bin/acts/acts_resolution-complete.pl?resolution=1976-A069 Acts of Convention: Resolution #1976-A069]. Retrieved 20013-7-14.</ref> In 1977, the first openly gay and lesbian priest was ordained by Bishop Paul Moore Jr. in New York.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/06/us/lesbian-ordained-episcopal-priest.html|title=LESBIAN ORDAINED EPISCOPAL PRIEST|last=Steinfels|first=Peter|date=1991-06-06|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-08-02}}</ref>
Various interpretations were held within the [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]] on this resolution, ranging from the majority of [[diocese]]s that now ordain non-celibate [[gay]], [[lesbian]], [[Bisexuality|bisexual]], and [[transgender]] [[clergy]] to the minority group who founded the [[Anglican Communion Network]] which currently opposes such ordinations. On 23 June 2005, [[Episcopal Church (United States)|The Episcopal Church]] defined its meaning in a 130-page document entitled "To Set Our Hope on Christ": <blockquote>We believe that God has been opening our eyes to acts of God that we had not known how to see before ... the eligibility for ordination of those in covenanted same-sex unions ... a person living in a same-gendered union may be eligible to lead the flock of Christ ... members of the Episcopal Church have discerned holiness in same-sex relationships and have come to support the blessing of such unions and the ordination or consecration of persons in those unions ... Their holiness stands in stark contrast with many sinful patterns of sexuality in the world ... The idea that there is only one correct way to read or interpret scripture is a rather modern idea.<ref>Jill Lawless, Associated Press, 21 June 2005. [http://aacblog.classicalanglican.net/archives/2005_06.html#000759 U.S. Episcopals Defend Openly Gay Bishop]. Accessed 17 July 2007.</ref></blockquote>
In July 2009, the [[General Convention of the Episcopal Church in the United States of America|General Convention]] voted to allow [[bishop]]s to [[blessing of same-sex unions in Christian churches|bless same-sex unions]], and also called for bishops to "collect and develop theological and liturgical resources" for possibly creating an [[Wedding|official rite]] for such ceremonies at the 2012 General Convention.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/16/us/16episcopal.html?_r=1 | work=The New York Times | title=Episcopal Bishops Give Ground on Gay Marriage | first=Laurie | last=Goodstein | date=16 July 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.edgeboston.com/index.php?ch=news&sc=&sc2=news&sc3=&id=94111 |title=Gays make advances at Episcopal confab |first=Chuck Colbert |date=24 July 2009 |publisher=[[Edge Media Network]]}}</ref>
In January 2010, the Reverend Mally Lloyd and the Reverend [[Katherine Hancock Ragsdale]], two prominent [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal]] priests, married in a [[Wedding|ceremony]] at the [[Cathedral Church of St. Paul (Boston)|Cathedral Church of St. Paul]] in [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]].<ref>[http://www.advocate.com/News/Daily_News/2011/01/06/Two_Lesbian_Priests_Tie_the_Knot/ Advocate:Two Lesbian Priests Tie the Knot] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110108005623/http://www.advocate.com/News/Daily_News/2011/01/06/Two_Lesbian_Priests_Tie_the_Knot/ |date=8 January 2011 }}</ref>
In 2012, the General Convention approved an official liturgy for blessing same-sex unions, called “The Witnessing and Blessing of a Lifelong Covenant,” while making it clear that it was not marriage. The action enabled priests to bestow the church’s blessing on gay couples even in states where same-sex marriage is illegal, subject to the approval of the bishops.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/11/us/episcopalians-approve-rite-to-bless-same-sex-unions.html?partner=rss&emc=rss |work=The New York Times |title=Episcopalians Approve Rite to Bless Same-Sex Unions |first=Laurie |last=Goodstein |date=2012-07-10}}</ref>
In 2015, the General Convention approved “canonical and liturgical changes to provide marriage equality for Episcopalians.” The canonical change eliminated “language defining marriage as between a man and a woman.” The liturgical change provided two marriage rites for use by same-sex or opposite-sex couples with consent of the priest and permission of the bishop.<ref>Episcopal News Service staff, “General Convention wrap-up: Historic actions, structural changes” (July 7, 2015). Online at http://episcopaldigitalnetwork.com/ens/2015/07/07/general-convention-wrap-up-historic-actions-structural-changes/.</ref>
=== Episcopal Church of Cuba === {{Main|Episcopal Church of Cuba}} At least one bishop of the extraprovincial diocese, Bishop Nerva Cot, stated that she supported the ordination of openly gay and lesbian priests.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cubaencuentro.com/txt/cuba/noticias/la-iglesia-episcopal-ordena-en-cuba-a-la-primera-mujer-obispo-de-america-latina-37113|title=La Iglesia Episcopal ordena en Cuba a la primera mujer obispo de América Latina|last=http://www.cubaencuentro.com/|first=Cubaencuentro.com,|website=www.cubaencuentro.com|access-date=2016-07-02}}</ref>
===Church in the Province of the West Indies=== {{Main|Church in the Province of the West Indies}} [[Archbishop]] Gomez has said [[Gene Robinson]]'s ordination is incompatible with [[Bible|Scripture]].<ref name=factfile /> In 2017, Archbishop John Holder stated that there is no biblical support for anti-sodomy laws and urged Jamaica to repeal its laws against gay and lesbian relationships.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/news/archbishop-of-the-wi-says_113834?profile=1606|title=Archbishop of the WI says Bible does not support anti-sodomy laws|last=Limited|first=Jamaica Observer|website=Jamaica Observer|access-date=2017-11-09}}</ref>
===Church of the Province of Central Africa=== {{Main|Church of the Province of Central Africa}} [[Archbishop]] Malango was quoted as stating [[Gene Robinson]]'s election "brought darkness, disappointment, sadness and grief" to his Church.<ref>Afrol News, 2 September 2003. [http://www.afrol.com/articles/10483 Ugandan Church attacks gay community]. Retrieved 18 July 2007.</ref>
===Anglican Church of Kenya=== {{Main|Anglican Church of Kenya}} [[Archbishop]] Nzimbi has strongly spoken against admitting non-celibate [[Sexual orientation|same-sex attracted]] people into the Church.<ref name=factfile />
In 2013, Archbishop [[Eliud Wabukala]], then the Primate of the church, "denounced a decision by the Church of England's House of Bishops to allow gay priests to become bishops."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201301072075.html|title=Kenya: Anglican Church Rejects Proposal for Gay Bishops|last=Wanyama|first=Henry|date=2013-01-07|newspaper=The Star (Nairobi)|access-date=2016-11-16}}</ref> He also opposed priests being allowed to enter into same-sex civil partnerships saying the Church of England "'seems to be advancing along the same path' as the US Episcopal Church and the Anglican Church of Canada which he accused of promoting 'a false gospel'."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2013/07/23/archbishop-of-kenya-warns-archbishop-of-canterbury-against-supporting-civil-partnerships/|title=Archbishop of Kenya warns Justin Welby against supporting civil partnerships|newspaper=PinkNews|access-date=2016-11-16}}</ref>
===Anglican Church of Korea=== {{Main|Anglican Church of Korea}} The Anglican Church of Korea is among the more liberal provinces in the Anglican Communion.<ref>{{cite web|title=Korean Catholic priests become Anglican and marry|url=http://ncronline.org/news/korean-catholic-priests-become-anglican-and-marry|website=ncronline.org|publisher=National Catholic Reporter|accessdate=February 22, 2016}}</ref> In 2015, a cleric, members, and congregations of the province participated in an LGBT Pride event and have been affirming of equal rights for gays and lesbians.<ref>{{cite web|title=Why Korea's Christians are leading the anti-gay charge: And how a handful of LGBT-affirming churches are fighting back|url=http://www.dailyxtra.com/world/news-and-ideas/news/korea’s-christian-churches-leading-the-anti-gay-charge-125870|website=dailyxtra.com|publisher=Daily Xtra|accessdate=February 22, 2016}}</ref> The Anglican Church in Korea has openly had discussions about human sexuality.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.penews.co.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=1202|title=교회에 번지는 '동성애' 논란…동성애자가 목사 안수를 받을 수 있는가 - 목장드림뉴스|access-date=2017-05-04|language=ko}}</ref>
===Church of Nigeria=== {{Main|Church of Nigeria}} The Church remains sharply opposed to homosexuality, calling it "a perversion of human dignity."<ref name=Message2nation>Peter Akinola, [http://www.anglican-nig.org/PH2006message2nation.htm Message to the nation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070312203933/http://www.anglican-nig.org/PH2006message2nation.htm |date=12 March 2007 }}. Retrieved 17 July 2007.</ref> In 2005, Archbishop [[Peter Akinola]] spoke out against the Church of England's decision to allow priests to enter into same-sex civil partnerships.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/revd.akinolas.response.to.church.of.england.civil.partnerships.stance/3642.htm|title=Revd Akinola's Response to Church of England Civil Partnerships Stance {{!}} Christian News on Christian Today|website=www.christiantoday.com|access-date=2016-11-16}}</ref>
In March 2009, the Church declared itself in full communion with the [[Anglican Church in North America]], a denomination formed by American and Canadian Anglicans who opposed their national churches' actions with regard to homosexuality and [[Marriage equality|equality]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://religionblog.dallasnews.com/archives/2009/03/church-of-nigeria-in-full-comm.html |title=Church of Nigeria in full communion with Anglican Church of North America |first=Sam |last=Hodges |publisher=''The Dallas Morning News'' |date=20 March 2009 |accessdate=11 September 2009}}</ref>
In 2013, Archbishop Nicholas Okoh opposed the Church of England's decision to allow gay bishops, even if celibate, to enter into civil unions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-anglican-africa-gay-idUKBRE90909Q20130110|title=African Anglicans denounce Church of England gay bishop rule|last=Editor|first=Tom Heneghan, Religion|newspaper=Reuters UK|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-11-16}}</ref>
=== Anglican Church in Central America === The [[Anglican Church in Central America]] consists of five churches representing different Central American countries. Each member church makes many of its own decisions. In 2013, priests and ministries in the Diocese of El Salvador began to advocate for the full inclusion of LGBT members.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://episcopaldigitalnetwork.com/ens/2013/03/27/la-formacion-de-un-ministerio-para-los-hbt-en-el-salvador/ | title = La formación de un ministerio para los HBT en El Salvador | website = Episcopal News Service | language = en-US | access-date = 2016-03-01 }}</ref> In 2014, the Episcopal Church of Costa Rica, a diocese of the province, took steps toward welcoming the LGBTQ community.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://episcopaldigitalnetwork.com/ens/2014/03/06/iglesia-de-costa-rica-toma-pasos-para-dar-la-bienvenida-a-la-comunidad-lgbtq/|title=Iglesia de Costa Rica toma pasos para dar la bienvenida a la comunidad LGBTQ|date=2014-03-06|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-06}}</ref> The Diocese of Guatemala elected the Rev Silvestre Enrique Romero as bishop coadjutor in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.diomass.org/diocesan-news/silvestre-romero-elected-bishop-coadjutor-diocese-guatemala|title=Silvestre Romero elected bishop coadjutor of Diocese of Guatemala {{!}} The Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts|website=www.diomass.org|access-date=2017-06-12}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Prior to being elected bishop, the Rev Romero served in [[Episcopal Church (United States)|The Episcopal Church (US)]], and offered to bless same-sex unions as priest-in-charge.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stpeterssalem.org/pages/wedding_guidelines.htm|title=St. Peter ~ San Pedro|website=www.stpeterssalem.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160731200807/http://www.stpeterssalem.org/pages/wedding_guidelines.htm#|archive-date=31 July 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Anglican Church of Mexico=== {{Main|Anglican Church of Mexico}}
The Anglican Church of Mexico, like the other North American provinces, has expressed in some particular instances more liberal views regarding gender and sexuality. However, Presiding Bishop Francisco Moreno has opposed same-sex unions and the current canons do not provide for them.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vanguardia.com.mx/articulo/anglicanos-y-mormones-contra-matrimonios-gay|title=Anglicanos y mormones contra matrimonios gay|website=Vanguardia|access-date=2016-06-18}}</ref> In 2007, then Presiding Bishop Carlos Touché-Porter became a patron of Inclusive Church advocating for '"a liberal, open church which is inclusive of all,' regardless of race, gender or sexuality".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.episcopalchurch.org/library/article/scotland-primus-becomes-co-patron-inclusive-church|title=SCOTLAND: Primus becomes co-patron of Inclusive Church {{!}} Episcopal Church|website=www.episcopalchurch.org|access-date=2016-07-06}}</ref> Former Presiding Bishop Carlos Touché-Porter also affirmed that Bishop Gene Robinson was not the first gay cleric, but that he was simply being honest.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Figueroa|first1=Héctor|title=Habrá obispo mexicana en unos años: Iglesia Anglicana|url=http://www.excelsior.com.mx/nacional/2014/07/20/971841|website=excelsior.com.mx|publisher=Excelsior|accessdate=February 10, 2016}}</ref> He also supported the ordination of openly gay clergy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/archbishops-gay-plea-640318|title=Archbishop's gay plea|last=Qureshi|first=Yakub|date=2007-10-03|access-date=2016-07-06}}</ref> Bishop Touché-Porter's diocese, the Diocese of Mexico, "permits clergy in same-sex relationships to serve in the ministry."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://geoconger.wordpress.com/2010/07/17/mexico-backs-anglican-covenant-the-church-of-england-newspaper-july-9-2010-p-5/|title=Mexico backs Anglican Covenant: The Church of England Newspaper, July 9, 2010 p 5|date=2010-07-17|website=Conger|access-date=2016-12-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.churchnewspaper.com/?s=Mexico|title=Mexico backs Anglican Covenant|last=Conger|first=George|date=August 7, 2010|website=churchnewspaper.com|publisher=The Church of England Newspaper|access-date=December 19, 2016}}</ref> Furthermore, in 2008, when Pope Benedict XVI approached the Anglican Church with the possibility of joining the Catholic Church over issues of sexuality, then Presiding Bishop Carlos reassured his province that he supported remaining within the Anglican Communion.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ramírez|first1=Mariana Viayra|title=Anglicanos mexicanos rechazan unirse a la Iglesia católica|url=http://www.cronica.com.mx/notas/2009/467560.html|website=cronica.com.mx|publisher=La Crónica|accessdate=February 10, 2016}}</ref>
Also in 2008, Bishop Sergio Carranza supported the ordination of gay clergy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://inchatatime.blogspot.com/2008/01/truly-orthodox-anglicans.html|title=An Inch At A Time: Reflections on the Journey: "THE TRULY ORTHODOX ANGLICANS"|last=Russell|first=Susan|date=2008-01-31|website=An Inch At A Time|access-date=2016-12-19}}</ref> Among the affirming churches, St. Mark's Anglican Church in Guadalajara, Jalisco is publicly supportive of gay, lesbian, and transgender members.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gaychurch.org/find_a_church/list-churches-by-country/?loc=Mexico|title=List Churches by Country - GayChurch.org|website=GayChurch.org|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-30}}</ref> Nevertheless, on the other side, Presiding Bishop Francisco Moreno, the current primate of the province, has indicated that he supports marriage as defined "between a man and a woman".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vanguardia.com.mx/articulo/anglicanos-y-mormones-contra-matrimonios-gay|title=Anglicanos y mormones contra matrimonios gay|access-date=2016-07-06}}</ref>
In 2015, at least one congregation "opened its doors" to bless same-gender couples.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://globalmedia.mx/noticia/45093/que-dios-bendiga-a-pareja-gay-que-se-caso-arzobispo|title=Que Dios bendiga a pareja gay que se casó: Arzobispo|website=GlobalMedia Noticias|language=es-ES|access-date=2016-06-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160803042733/http://globalmedia.mx/noticia/45093/que-dios-bendiga-a-pareja-gay-que-se-caso-arzobispo|archivedate=3 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://pulsoslp.com.mx/2015/08/21/anglicanos-abren-las-puertas-a-gays-en-slp-bendicion-de-parejas-homosexuales-en-analisis/|title=Anglicanos abren las puertas a gays en SLP; bendición de parejas homosexuales, en análisis - Pulso Diario de San Luis|website=pulsoslp.com.mx|access-date=2016-06-17}}</ref> The church will be discussing same-gender unions at its General Synod.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://pulsoslp.com.mx/2015/08/24/poco-probable-que-iglesia-catolica-modifique-codigo-canonico-para-bendecir-a-gays-cabrero/|title=Poco probable, que Iglesia católica modifique código canónico para bendecir a gays: Cabrero - Pulso Diario de San Luis|website=pulsoslp.com.mx|access-date=2016-06-17}}</ref>
===Anglican Church of Southern Africa=== {{Main|Anglican Church of Southern Africa}}
The canon law of the Anglican Church of Southern Africa states that "marriage by divine institution is a lifelong and exclusive union partnership between one man and one woman" and makes no provision for same-sex weddings or for blessing same-sex civil unions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://anglicanchurchsa.org/canons/chapter-c34-disipline/|title=C34: OF HOLY MATRIMONY – Anglican Church of Southern Africa|website=anglicanchurchsa.org|language=en-ZA|access-date=2017-12-21}}</ref> The [[Diocese of Saldanha Bay]] has approved the blessing of same-sex civil unions as a provison on the diocesan level.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.iol.co.za/capetimes/news/churchs-decision-to-bless-same-sex-unions-hailed-17390688|title=Church's decision to bless same-sex unions hailed {{!}} Cape Times|access-date=2018-10-08|language=en}}</ref> At the same time, the church does not have an official stance on homosexuality itself.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/in_depth/3226753.stm|title=Anglican Church around the world|date=2008-07-15|access-date=2018-02-24|language=en-GB}}</ref> However, it has been reported of current Archbishop Thabo Makgoba that "The Anglican Primate, [is] one among few church leaders in Africa to support same-sex marriage."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/why.this.archbishop.wept.when.his.church.rejected.gays/96936.htm|title=Why This Archbishop Wept When His Church Rejected Same-Sex Blessings {{!}} Christian News on Christian Today|website=www.christiantoday.com|access-date=2016-12-12}}</ref> Archbishop Makgoba and his working group on human sexuality have proposed a motion “… to amend Canon 34 which will enable ministry to those in Same Sex Unions and the LGBTI Community in the context in which ACSA operates in Southern Africa."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.churchnewspaper.com/49159/archives|title=South Africa Church plans to amend marriage Canon – ChurchNewspaper.com|website=www.churchnewspaper.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-17}}</ref>
A previous archbishop, [[Desmond Tutu]], said that: "The [[Jesus]] I worship is not likely to collaborate with those who vilify and persecute an already oppressed minority [...]. I could not myself keep quiet whilst people were being penalised for something about which they could do nothing, their sexuality. For it is so improbable that any sane, normal person would deliberately choose a lifestyle exposing him or her to so much vilification, opprobrium and physical abuse, even death. To discriminate against our sisters and brothers who are lesbian or gay on grounds of their sexual orientation for me is as totally unacceptable and unjust as Apartheid ever was.<ref>Archbishop Desmond Tutu, 1 February 2004.[http://jmm.aaa.net.au/articles/12039.htm Sermon at Southwark Cathedral]. Accessed 22 March 2007.</ref>"
Another former archbishop, [[Njongonkulu Ndungane]], has criticised other African churches regarding homosexuality and said that the church's attention should be focused on other concerns such as [[AIDS]] and [[poverty]]. Nevertheless, Ndungane expressed publicly his disapproval of [[same-sex marriage]] when it was legalised in [[South Africa]]: "As far as we are concerned as a church, our understanding of marriage is between a man and a woman. And as a church, and the Anglican Church in particular, we have said no to same-sex unions."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://changingattitude.org.uk/archives/2083|title=Archbishop Njongonkulu of Cape Town declares same-sex marriages unchristian 9 December 2004|work=changingattitude.org.uk|access-date=3 July 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714182152/http://changingattitude.org.uk/archives/2083|archive-date=14 July 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> However, in 2016, the bishops of the Anglican Church of Southern Africa voted to affirm members in same-gender marriages as fully equal members of the Church.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.umc.org/what-we-believe/support-for-the-religious-coalition-for-reproductive-choice | title = Support for the Religious Coalition for Reproductive Choice - The United Methodist Church | last = Communications | first = United Methodist | website = The United Methodist Church | access-date = 2016-02-25 }}</ref> Bishop Raphael Hess, in Saldanha Bay, has backed same-sex marriage and is proposing a way to allow gay priests to marry.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.livingchurch.org/bishop-backs-same-sex-marriage|title=Bishop Backs Same-sex Marriage - The Living Church|website=www.livingchurch.org|access-date=2016-05-24}}</ref> Archbishop Tutu also gave his daughter and her partner a blessing.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://howafrica.com/photo-archbishop-desmond-tutu-blesses-gay-union-of-his-daughter/|title=South African Archbishop Desmond Tutu Blesses Gay Union of His Daughter - How Africa|date=2016-01-05|website=How Africa|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-12}}</ref>
Additionally, the Anglican Church of Southern Africa does not have an official policy regarding the ordination of openly gay or lesbian clergy and, thus, some may identify as LGBT depending on their diocese.<ref name=":6">{{cite web|title=Global trend: World's oldest Protestant churches now ordain gays and lesbians|url=http://www.ucc.org/global-trend-worlds-oldest|website=ucc.org|publisher=United Church of Christ|accessdate=February 21, 2016}}</ref> In 2003, for example, the Rev. Rowan Smith, the dean of St. George's Cathedral in Cape Town, was warmly celebrated by his congregation after coming out as gay.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/World/News/Churchgoers-embrace-gay-priest-20030810|title=Churchgoers embrace gay priest|website=News24|access-date=2016-04-12}}</ref> The Rev. Douglas Torr also came out to his congregation in Johannesburg.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200311110202.html|title=South Africa: Priest Outs Himself Before Sermon|last=Mlangeni|first=Bongiwe|date=November 9, 2003|website=allafrica.com|publisher=Sundaytimes.co.uk|access-date=June 30, 2016}}</ref> Moreover, the Rt. Rev. Mervyn Castle, who is openly gay and celibate, was consecrated suffragan bishop in Cape Town.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yYHcK6kWcPAC|title=Aliens in the Household of God: Homosexuality and Christian Faith in South Africa|last=Germond|first=Paul|date=1997-01-01|publisher=New Africa Books|isbn=9780864863300|language=en}}</ref> Still, while gay and lesbian clergy may be locally ordained, the national church has not yet developed liturgies to bless same-gender unions.
Nevertheless, the Diocese of Cape Town, in 2009, did vote in favour of recognising same-gender unions pastorally and the diocese committed itself to studying the issue further.<ref name=":8">{{cite web|title=Resolution of the Diocese of Cape Town on Ministry to Gays and Lesbians in Covenanted Partnerships|url=http://archbishop.anglicanchurchsa.org/2009/08/resolution-of-diocese-of-cape-town-on.html|website=anglicanchurchsa.org|publisher=Anglican Church of Southern Africa|accessdate=February 21, 2016}}</ref> The vote in 2009 "[had] taken a small step towards accepting gay people in 'faithful, committed relationships.'"<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/church-makes-key-decision-on-gay-couples-456065|title=Church makes key decision on gay couples {{!}} IOL|access-date=2016-07-08}}</ref> The resolution also said that it is "Affirming a pastoral response to same-sex partnerships of faithful commitment in our parish families;"<ref name=":8" /> Also in 2009, Archbishop Thabo Makgoba said that "[g]ays and lesbians can be leaders within the Anglican Church of Southern Africa as long as they remain celibate, its synod of bishops has declared."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.anglicanjournal.com/articles/sexual-orientation-no-barrier-to-church-leadership-in-southern-africa-8688|title=Sexual orientation no barrier to church leadership in Southern Africa|website=www.anglicanjournal.com|access-date=2017-05-12}}</ref>
In 2013, the Provincial Synod adopted a resolution that "urged its bishops to provide guidelines for giving pastoral care to same-sex couples who have entered civil unions under South African law."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.episcopalchurch.org/library/article/southern-africa-church-considers-pastoral-response-civil-unions|title=Southern Africa: Church considers pastoral response to civil unions|date=2013-10-04|work=Episcopal Church|access-date=2017-05-12|language=en}}</ref> The resolution also:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.anglicannews.org/news/2013/10/anglican-church-of-southern-africa-considers-pastoral-response-to-civil-unions.aspx|title=Anglican Church of Southern Africa considers Pastoral Response to Civil Unions|website=www.anglicannews.org|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-05-12}}</ref> # Affirms: ## That God calls us to love and minister to all people, regardless of their sexual orientation, while at the same time upholding God's standards of holiness; ## That this is a highly complex and emotive area which affects many people deeply and has a far reaching impact on the mission of the Church. In 2016, Bishop Raphael Hess of Sadanha Bay gave permission for an Anglican priest to officiate at a service of celebration for the Rev. Mpho Tutu and her partner.<ref name=":0" /> When Tutu surrendered her licence to avoid controversy, Bishop Hess stated that he "hoped it would be short-lived" and that he is proposing to change policy to welcome her back. Her father, Desmond Tutu, gave "a father's blessing".<ref name="telegraph.co.uk" />
Currently, priests may not enter into a same-sex marriage, but the church does allow "same-sex relationships if they are celibate."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jun/09/mpho-tutu-van-furth-its-painful-to-step-down-from-my-priestly-ministry|title=Desmond Tutu's daughter: 'painful' to give up ministry after marrying woman|last=correspondent|first=Harriet Sherwood Religion|date=2016-06-09|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-12-12}}</ref> Also in 2016, Archbishop Makgoba said "we also tried at the Synod of Bishops to draw up guidelines for clergy wanting to bless couples in same-sex unions, or who want to enter same-sex unions themselves ... On this issue, I had to report back to the Synod, the only agreement we reached is that we were not of one mind".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.episcopalcafe.com/synod-of-bishops-of-the-anglican-church-of-southern-africa/|title=Synod of Bishops of the Anglican Church of Southern Africa|date=2016-02-23|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-24}}</ref> Yet, the bishops did agree that LGBT people, including members in same-sex marriages, are affirmed as "full members" of the church.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/local/2016/02/22/Anglican-bishops-declare-gay%E2%80%9A-lesbian-couples-full-members-of-the-church|title=Anglican bishops declare gay‚ lesbian couples 'full members' of the church|last=Digital|first=TMG|website=Times LIVE|access-date=2016-07-24}}</ref>
The [[Diocese of Saldanha Bay]] proposed the blessing of same-gender unions and the licensing of LGBTI priests in civil marriages.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.anglicannews.org/news/2016/08/southern-african-synod-to-consider-blessing-same-sex-civil-unions.aspx|title=Southern African synod to consider blessing same-sex civil unions|website=www.anglicannews.org|access-date=2016-08-18}}</ref> During the provincial synod, the proposal did not receive enough votes and was not passed.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://episcopaldigitalnetwork.com/ens/2016/09/30/anglican-church-of-southern-africa-rejects-blessing-of-same-sex-civil-unions/|title=Anglican Church of Southern Africa rejects blessing of same-sex civil unions|date=2016-09-30|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-30}}</ref> Archbishop Thabo Makgoba, however, declared that "all is not lost". He said the issue might hopefully be taken up again at the next provincial synod in 2019. He also said the issue could be discussed at the local level in parishes and dioceses.<ref name=":1" /> Makgoba further noted how relatively liberal the province is saying "As it was, the degree of support for the motion was quite substantial if you compare us to other African provinces of the Anglican Church, most of which are vigorously opposed to same-sex unions in any form."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://archbishop.anglicanchurchsa.org/2016/10/the-anglican-church-of-southern-africas.html|title=The Anglican Church of Southern Africa's debate on human sexuality - Archbishop Thabo Makgoba|website=archbishop.anglicanchurchsa.org|access-date=2018-06-06}}</ref> He also voiced his support for same-sex marriage.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/why.this.archbishop.wept.when.his.church.rejected.gays/96936.htm|title=Why This Archbishop Wept When His Church Rejected Same-Sex Blessings {{!}} Christian News on Christian Today|website=www.christiantoday.com|access-date=2016-10-05}}</ref>
The [[Diocese of False Bay]] has also been supportive of LGBTI clergy and members having celebrated the ministry of one of its openly gay priests.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.falsebaydiocese.org.za/2010/04/24/sermon-upon-the-retirement-of-dean-rowan-smith/|title=Sermon Upon the Retirement of Dean Rowan Smith {{!}} Diocese of False Bay|last=admin|access-date=2016-09-30}}</ref> The [[Anglican Diocese of Pretoria|Diocese of Pretoria]] joined the list of dioceses that support same-sex marriage in the Anglican Church.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/gauteng/more-ructions-in-anglican-church-over-same-sex-marriage-11238628|title=More ructions in Anglican church over same-sex marriage {{!}} IOL News|access-date=2017-09-20|language=en}}</ref> At least one priest, who is in a same-sex relationship with his partner, has spoken to the press acknowledging that the church ordained him knowing of his relationship.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2016-10-06-anglican-church-speaks-with-two-tongues-on-same-sex-unions|title=Anglican church speaks with two tongues on same-sex unions|last=Collison|first=Carl|newspaper=The M&G Online|access-date=2016-12-12}}</ref>
In a pastoral letter published on March 2, 2017, the Bench of Bishops said that they continue to discuss "the Pastoral Guidelines for ministry to those in same-sex relationships, which are still incomplete. We asked Archbishop Thabo to set up a small group of Bishops to work on completing them, together with others who could help the process."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://anglicanchurchsa.org/a-pastoral-letter-from-your-bishops-2/|title=A Pastoral Letter From Your Bishops – Anglican Church of Southern Africa|website=anglicanchurchsa.org|language=en-ZA|access-date=2017-05-04}}</ref> Archbishop Thabo is proposing a change to the canons following that process.
===Episcopal Church of the Sudan=== {{Main|Episcopal Church of the Sudan}}
The Primate of the [[Province of the Episcopal Church of South Sudan and Sudan|Episcopal Church of the Sudan]], [[Archbishop]] [[Daniel Deng Bul]], on 22 July at a public press conference during the 2008 [[Lambeth Conferences|Lambeth Conference]] called for [[Bishop]] [[Gene Robinson]] to resign, and for all those who had participated in his consecration to confess their sins to the conference.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.episcopalchurch.org/79901_99260_ENG_Print.html |title=Sudanese primate wants Robinson's resignation |publisher=The Episcopal Church |location=New York, NY, USA |last=Schjonberg |first=Mary Frances |date=22 July 2008 |accessdate=4 October 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080803032301/http://www.episcopalchurch.org/79901_99260_ENG_Print.html |archivedate=3 August 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Anglican Church of Tanzania=== {{Main|Anglican Church of Tanzania}} In November 2003, responding to the consecration of [[Bishop]] [[Gene Robinson]], [[Archbishop]] [[Donald Mtetemela]] stated his belief that homosexuality is against [[Bible|biblical]] teaching: "The Anglican Church of Tanzania believes that homosexuality is contrary to the teaching of the Word of God. It is a sin."<ref name="Tanzania">Afrol News, 13 November 2003. [http://www.afrol.com/articles/10473 Church of Tanzania breaks ties with US church]. Retrieved 22 March 2007.</ref> Mtetemela declared that the [[Anglican Church of Tanzania|Church of Tanzania]] was no longer in communion with [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]] bishops who participated in the [[consecration]] of Robinson, and those who permit the [[Blessing of same-sex unions in Christian churches|blessing of same-sex unions]].<ref name="Tanzania"/>
===Church of the Province of Uganda=== {{Main|Church of Uganda|l1=Church of the Province of Uganda}} The Ugandan church cut ties with its North American counterparts over homosexuality. It declared itself in full communion with the [[Anglican Church in North America]], a denomination not recognised by the Anglican Communion that was formed by lay and [[clergy]] members who had left [[Episcopal Church (United States)|The Episcopal Church]] and the [[Anglican Church of Canada]] over matters of [[LGBT]] inclusion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acnaassembly.org/index2.php/acna/page/109 |title=Church of Uganda Declares itself in Full Communion with Anglican Church in North America |author=Church of Uganda |publisher=Anglican Church in North America |accessdate=11 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090628104434/http://www.acnaassembly.org/index2.php/acna/page/109 |archivedate=28 June 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In 2005, Archbishop Orombi, then the leader of the Church of Uganda, criticised the Church of England for permitting priests to enter into same-sex civil partnerships.<ref name=":3" /> In 2013, Archbishop Stanley Ntagali maintained opposition to clergy in civil unions opposing the Church of England's decision to allow bishops to register a civil partnership.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1312365/ntagali-attacks-church-england-gay-bishops|title=Ntagali attacks Church of England over gay bishops|newspaper=www.newvision.co.ug|access-date=2016-12-17}}</ref> Archbishop Ntagali stated that “to allow clergy in civil partnerships to be eligible to become Bishops is really no different from allowing gay Bishops. This decision violates our Biblical faith and agreements within the Anglican Communion.”<ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url=http://www.churchnewspaper.com/30492/archives|title=African outrage over civil partnership decision|last=Conger|first=George|date=January 16, 2013|website=churchnewspaper.com|access-date=October 9, 2017}}</ref> Ntagali compared England's decision to those made in other western Anglican provinces. “Sadly we must also declare that if the Church of England continues in this contrary direction we must further separate ourselves from it and we are prepared to take the same actions as those prompted by the decisions of The Episcopal Church (USA) and the Anglican Church of Canada ten years ago.”<ref name=":9" />
=== Church of Melanesia === {{Main|Church of Melanesia}}In 1998, the Council of Bishops requested that the Rt Rev Terry Brown "draft a study paper on homosexuality for the Church of Melanesia ...".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rci.rutgers.edu/~lcrew/dojustice/j194.html|title=Further Reflections on Homosexuality, Christian Faith and the Church|last=Brown|first=Terry|date=2000|website=rci.rutgers.edu|publisher=Rutgers|access-date=May 3, 2016}}</ref> In 2007, Bishop Terry Brown, a former Bishop of Malaita reflected on his experience "as an 'out' gay man serving as bishop".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.episcopalcafe.com/another_gay_bishop/|title=Another Gay bishop|date=2007-09-07|website=Episcopal Cafe|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-03|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160220091332/http://www.episcopalcafe.com/another_gay_bishop/|archivedate=20 February 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== Spanish Reformed Episcopal Church === {{Main|Spanish Reformed Episcopal Church}}
On March 22, 2017, the Synod of the Spanish Reformed Episcopal Church released a statement of support expressing its solidarity with the [[Spanish Evangelical Church]] after the latter had accepted same-sex relationships.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.periodistadigital.com/religion/espana/2017/03/22/religion-iglesia-confesiones-espana-madrid-los-anglicanos-se-solidarizan-con-la-iglesia-evangelica-espanola.shtml|title=Los anglicanos se solidarizan con la Iglesia Evangélica Española|last=Madrid|first=Ministros anglicanos de|access-date=2017-05-04}}</ref> In supporting the Spanish Evangelical Church, the Episcopal Synod joined LGBT advocacy groups by protesting its removal from the Evangelical Council of Madrid.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://protestantedigital.com/ciudades/41763/Solidaridad_de_IERE_y_colectivos_LGTB_con_la_IEE_en_contra_del_CEM|title=Anglicanos y colectivos LGTB apoyan una iglesia inclusiva dentro del CEM|website=protestantedigital|language=en|access-date=2017-05-04}}</ref>

[[File:Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, Bernhard Christoph Francke.jpg|thumb|Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz]] [[Image:Samuel Clarke.jpg|thumb|Samuel Clarke.]] The '''Leibniz–Clarke correspondence''' was a [[scientific]], [[theological]] and [[philosophical]] [[debate]] conducted in an exchange of letters between the [[Germany|German]] thinker [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz]] and [[Samuel Clarke]], an [[England|English]] supporter of [[Isaac Newton]] during the years 1715 and 1716. The exchange began because of a letter Leibniz wrote to [[Caroline of Ansbach]], in which he remarked that Newtonian physics was detrimental to [[natural theology]]. Eager to defend the Newtonian view, Clarke responded, and the correspondence continued until the death of Leibniz in 1716.<ref>Rowe, p. 8</ref>
Although a variety of subjects is touched on in the letters, the main interest for modern readers is in the dispute between the [[Absolute time and space|absolute]] theory of [[space]] favoured by Newton and Clarke, and Leibniz's [[Relational space|relational]] approach. Also important is the conflict between Clarke's and Leibniz's opinions on [[free will]] and whether God must create the [[best of all possible worlds]].<ref>Rowe, p. 4</ref>
Leibniz had published only a book on moral matters, the ''[[Theodicy|Theodicée]]'' (1710), and his more metaphysical views had never been exposed to a sufficient extent, so the collected letters were met with interest by their contemporaries. The priority dispute between [[Leibniz and Newton calculus controversy|Leibniz and Newton about the calculus]] was still fresh in the public's mind and it was taken as a matter of course that it was Newton himself who stood behind Clarke's replies.
==Editions== The Leibniz-Clarke letters were first published under Clarke's name in the year following Leibniz' death.<ref>''A Collection of Papers, which passed between the late Learned Mr. Leibniz, and Dr. Clarke, In the Years 1715 and 1716'', by Samuel Clarke D.D. (London: James Knapton, 1717)</ref> He wrote a preface, took care of the translation from French, added notes and some of his own writing. In 1720 [[Pierre Desmaizeaux]] published a similar volume in a French translation,<ref>''Recueil de pièces diverses sur la philosophie la religion et l'histoire par Leibniz, Clarke et Newton'', publiées par Pierre Desmaizeaux, Amsterdam, 1720</ref> including quotes from Newton's work. It is quite certain that for both editions the opinion of Newton himself has been sought and Leibniz left at a disadvantage.<ref>Bertoloni-Melli D., ''Newton and the Leibniz-Clarke correspondence'', The Cambridge Companion to Newton, eds. I. B. Cohen and G. E. Smith, Cambridge University Press, 2002.</ref> However the German translation of the correspondence published by Kohler, also in 1720,<ref>''Merckwurdige Schriften welche . . . zwischen dem Herrn Baron von Leibniz und dem Herrn D. Clarke über besondere Materien der naturlichen Religion'' in Franzos. und Englischer Sprache gewechselt und . . . in teutscher Sprache herausgegeben worden von Heinrich Kohler, Frankfurt and Leipzig (Jena), 1720: there was a preface by [[Christian Wolff (philosopher)|Christian Wolff]] and a reply to Clarke's last letter in behalf of Leibniz by Ludwig Philipp Thümmig; it appeared also in the latin translation from 1740.</ref> contained a reply to Clarke's last letter which Leibniz had not been able to answer. The letters have been reprinted in most collections of Leibniz' works and regularly published in stand alone editions.<ref>A full list is given in Alexander H., ''The Leibniz-Clarke Correspondence'', with extracts from Newton's ''Principia'' and ''Opticks'', edited with an introduction and notes, Manchester, 1955 (and reeditions); for a more recent edition see e.g. ''G. W. Leibniz and Samuel Clarke: Correspondence'', Edited, with Introduction, by Roger Ariew, Hackett Publishing Co. Inc. Indianapolis/Cambridge, 2000.</ref>

This page lists philosophers from [[Canada]].

{{Spanish name|Carrera|Molina}} {{Infobox person | name = Margarita Carrera Molina | image = Margarita_Carrera.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth date|1929|09|16|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Guatemala City]], [[Guatemala]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2018|3|31|1929|09|16|df=y}} | death_place = Guatemala City, Guatemala | nationality = | other_names = Margarita Carrera de Wever | occupation = writer, philosopher, educator | years_active = 1957–2018 | known_for = | notable_works = }}
'''Margarita Carrera Molina''' (16 September 1929 – 31 March 2018) was a Guatemalan philosopher, professor and writer. She was a member of the [[Academia Guatemalteca de la Lengua]] and the 1996 laureate of the [[Miguel Ángel Asturias National Prize in Literature]].
==Early life== [[File:Margaritacarrera1940.jpg|thumb|Carrera as a child]] Margarita Carrera Molina was born 16 September 1929 in Guatemala City to Frenchman Antonio Carrera Martello and Josefina Molina Llardén. Her father committed suicide when she was a child and she had to work to help support her family, going to night school to learn.<ref name="Revista D">{{cite journal|last1=Montenegro|first1=Gustavo Adolfo|title=Margarita Carrera: Margarita, está brava la mar|journal=Revista D|date=19 February 2006|issue= 85|publisher=Prensa Libre|location=Guatemala City, Guatemala|language=Spanish}}</ref> She was the first female graduate in Literature from [[Universidad de San Carlos de Guatemala]] in 1957.<ref name="dict">{{cite book|last1=Meza Márquez|first1=Consuelo|title=Diccionario bibliográfico de narradoras centroamericanas con obra publicada entre 1890 y 2010|date=2011|isbn=978-607-8227-43-3|edition=1|language=es|pages=217-219}}</ref>
==Career== From 1957 she was employed as a university professor at her alma mater, as well as [[Rafael Landívar University]] and [[Universidad del Valle de Guatemala]].<ref name=Tribute>{{cite news|last1=Arce|first1=Maria Mercedes|title=Honores para Margarita Carrera|url=http://www.dca.gob.gt/index.php/entertainment-2/item/25859-honores-para-margarita|accessdate=29 June 2015|publisher=Diario de Centro América|date=15 February 2015|location=Guatemala|language=Spanish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150629194456/http://www.dca.gob.gt/index.php/entertainment-2/item/25859-honores-para-margarita|archivedate=29 June 2015|df=}}</ref> She was a lecturer at the [[Autonomous University of Madrid]] and served as guest writer on numerous international congresses held in Costa Rica, France, Germany, France, Germany, Mexico, Panama, Puerto Rico, Spain, Sweden, the US and Venezuela.<ref name=Tribute /> She was the first woman to ever become a member of the [[Academia Guatemalteca de la Lengua]] in 1967.<ref name="prensalibre">{{cite news|last1=Vicente|first1=Alfredo|title=Fallece la escritora guatemalteca y columnista de Prensa Libre Margarita Carrera|url=http://www.prensalibre.com/vida/escenario/fallece-la-escritora-guatemalteca-y-columnista-de-prensa-libre-margarita-carrera|accessdate=2 April 2018|work=Prensa Libre|date=31 March 2018|language=es|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180401212811/http://www.prensalibre.com/vida/escenario/fallece-la-escritora-guatemalteca-y-columnista-de-prensa-libre-margarita-carrera|archivedate=1 April 2018|df=}}</ref>
Carrera joined the International Writing Program at the [[University of Iowa]], in Iowa City, IA in 1982.<ref name=Tribute /> From 1993 she worked as a columnist for ''Prensa Libre'' of Guatemala and published in many other newspapers, including ''Diario de Centro America'', ''La Hora'', and ''El Imparcial''.<ref name="elPeriodico">{{cite news|last1=Aceituno|first1=Luis|title=Un adiós a Margarita Carrera|url=https://elperiodico.com.gt/oculta/2018/04/02/un-adios-a-margarita-carrera/|accessdate=2 April 2018|work=elPeriodico|date=2 April 2018|language=es|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180402121655/https://elperiodico.com.gt/oculta/2018/04/02/un-adios-a-margarita-carrera/|archivedate=2 April 2018|df=}}</ref> She wrote two columns at ''Prensa Libre'' weekly, in addition to having published twenty books.<ref name="20 books">{{cite news|title=Poesía: El lenguaje de Margarita Carrera|url=http://www.guatevision.com/poesia-el-lenguaje-de-margarita-carrera/|accessdate=29 June 2015|publisher=Guate Vision|date=9 February 2015|location=Guatemala|language=Spanish|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150701193105/http://www.guatevision.com/poesia-el-lenguaje-de-margarita-carrera/|archivedate=1 July 2015|df=}}</ref> In 1996, she was awarded the [[Miguel Ángel Asturias National Prize in Literature]].<ref name="prensalibre" />
In an interview in her 70s, Carrera said that she often wrote about men she found interesting and whom she studied to help her understand the man she never knew, her father. Among those she studied and wrote about were Argentine writer [[Jorge Luis Borges]], Austrian psychoanalyst [[Sigmund Freud]], Spanish poet [[Juan Ramón Jiménez]], German philosopher [[Friedrich Nietzsche]] and Spanish philosopher [[Miguel de Unamuno]]. After his death, she read about [[Juan José Gerardi Conedera]] and ended up writing a novel about his life: ''En la mirilla del jaguar: biografía novelada de Monseñor Gerardi'', published in 2002.<ref name="Revista D" /> She was awarded the Monseñor Gerardi Conedera Order in 2004.<ref name=Tribute />
==Personal life and death== Carrera was married for seven years and divorced. She had two children.<ref name="Revista D" /> Carrera died in Guatemala on 31 March 2018 at the age of 88.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fallece Margarita Carrera, Premio Nacional de Literatura de 1996 en Guatemala|url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/vida/20180331/442091254867/fallece-margarita-carrera-premio-nacional-de-literatura-de-1996-en-guatemala.html|accessdate=1 April 2018|work=La Vanguardia|language=es}}</ref>
==Awards== *1981 Golden Quetzal for "Ensayos contra reloj"<ref name="Margarita Carrera">{{cite web|title=Margarita Carrera|url=http://www.deguate.com/infocentros/personajes/poetas/margarita.html|website=de Guate|publisher=de Guate|accessdate=29 June 2015|location=Guatemala|language=Spanish}}</ref> *1982 First Prize in poetry for "Mujer y soledades" from Juegos Florales Centroamericanos y de Panamá, [[Quetzaltenango]], Guatemala<ref name="Margarita Carrera" /> *1982 Finalist in the XI Anagram Essay Prize in [[Barcelona]], Spain<ref name="Margarita Carrera" /> *1986 First Prize in poetry for "Signo XX" from Juegos Florales Hispanoamericanos, [[Quetzaltenango]], Guatemala<ref name="Margarita Carrera" /> *1988 Vicenta Laparra Order<ref name="prensalibre" /> *1996 Miguel Ángel Asturias National Prize in Literature<ref name="Margarita Carrera" /> *2000 Meritorious Service Medal Universidad de San Carlos de Guatemala<ref name="elPeriodico" /> *2000 Communications award from UNICEF<ref name="prensalibre" /> *2004 Monseñor Gerardi Conedera Order<ref name="prensalibre" />

{{Infobox philosopher | name = Max Adler | image = | alt = | caption = | other_names = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1873|01|15|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Vienna]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1937|06|28|1873|01|15|df=y}} | death_place = Vienna | residence = Vienna | nationality = Austrian | era = [[20th-century philosophy]] | region = [[Western philosophy]] | religion = | school_tradition = [[Austromarxism]] | main_interests = Social philosophy, educational reform, social democracy | books = | notable_ideas = | alma_mater = [[University of Vienna]] (Dr.jur., 1896) | institutions = [[University of Vienna]] | influences = [[Karl Marx]], [[Max Stirner]] | influenced = [[Lucien Goldmann]] | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = }} '''Max Adler''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|æ|d|l|ər}};<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/adler "Adler"]. ''[[Random House Webster's Unabridged Dictionary]]''.</ref> {{IPA-de|ˈaːdlɐ|lang}}; 15 January 1873 – 28 June 1937) was an Austrian jurist, politician and [[Social philosophy|social philosopher]]; his theories were of central importance to [[Austromarxism]]. He was a brother of [[Oskar Adler]].
== Life == Max Adler obtained his doctorate in law in 1896, and became a professional lawyer. He began to teach in the “Schönbrunn Circle” in the early summer of 1919. Max Winter, the deputy mayor of Vienna, was able to make rooms available in the main building of Schönbrunn Castle for the ''Kinderfreunde Österreich'' (an Austrian association for children and families). In the ''Schönbrunner Erzieherschule'', where young people were trained to be teachers, Max Adler and his colleagues [[Wilhelm Jerusalem]], [[Alfred Adler]], [[Marianne Pollak]], [[Josef Luitpold Stern]] and [[Otto Felix Kanitz]] were able to realize practical educational reforms. In 1920 he qualified at [[Vienna University]], where he became Extraordinary Professor of [[Sociology]] and [[Social philosophy]]. From 1919 to 1921 he was a Social-Democratic member of the regional parliament of [[Niederösterreich]].<ref>[http://www.landtag-noe.at/service/politik/landtag/Abgeordnete/ZAbgA/Adler-M.pdf landtag-noe.at]</ref> Adler was active in Adult Education, and from 1904 to 1925, with [[Rudolf Hilferding]], editor of ''"Marx-Studien"''.
== Works == [[File:Adler - Sozialistische Idee der Befreiung bei Karl Marx, 1918 - 5172958.tif|thumb|''Sozialistische Idee der Befreiung bei [[Karl Marx]]'', 1918]] Max Adler’s first theoretical work of note was a study ''"Max Stirner. Ein Beitrag zur Feststellung des Verhältnisses von Socialismus und Individualismus"'' (1894). The title sets the agenda for Adler’s later theoretical activities. Although this study of Marx’s scorned opponent seriously antagonized [[Marxism|Marxist]] Party theorists, and so remained unpublished, [[Max Stirner|Stirner]] remained an influence on Adler’s thinking throughout his life. Adler’s biographer Alfred Pfabigan, upon sight of his unpublished papers, was surprised by his “intellectual relationship with Stirner owing to its high degree of continuity”.<ref>Alfred Pfabigan: ''Max Adler''. Frankfurt/Main: Campus 1982, p. 15</ref>
Because Adler wanted to operate within the framework of the rising [[Social democracy|Social Democratic]] movement, he was highly circumspect in his subsequent references to Stirner, and, while continuing to accord him great significance as Marx’s “psychological counterpart”, initially adopted most aspects of the doctrine of [[Historical materialism|Historical Materialism]]: the essence of history is class struggle, and its realization entails a union of theory with revolutionary practice. He envisaged “ever greater harmony and perfection” arising from the contradictions inherent in the then state of society, until the proletariat, in the course of its revolution, would finally see “the pursuit of its own class interests” coincide with “the solidarity of society”. In a departure from [[orthodox Marxism]], Adler’s conception reduces the [[dialectic]] to a mere sociological methodology, not expressive of any specific dialectic intrinsic to the historical process. In common with other theorists of the [[Second International]], such as [[Karl Kautsky]] and [[Karl Liebknecht]], Adler also rejects the association between [[Scientific Socialism]] and [[Materialism]]: true Marxism was “in reality social idealism“. For Adler, [[Historical materialism|Historical Materialism]] essentially becomes [[subjective idealism]]. In all consistency, his particular interest then turned to producing an epistemological critique of [[Sociology]], combining Marxist themes with [[Immanuel Kant|Kantian]] [[transcendentalism]]. According to Adler, “the individual consciousness is a priori socialized”, insofar as every logical judgement already and necessarily includes reference to a multitude of assenting subjects; Adler’s ‘social a priori’ transcendentally implies the possibility of social reality.
Adler’s contributions to a Marxist general theory of the state emerged in the course of disputes with [[Hans Kelsen]] and [[Hermann Heller (Jurist)|Hermann Heller]]. Criticizing the formal concept of [[democracy]], Adler distinguished between political democracy, as a manifestation of the hegemony of the bourgeoisie, and a social democracy, in which oppression was to be removed along with social differences, the whole to be replaced by “solidarity-based administrative reform” of society. For Adler, the establishment of a socialist society remained linked to the ‘dismantling of the machinery of the state’ along Marxist lines. Adler the politician permitted no compromises with the so-called "[[social chauvinism]]", or majority-Socialist “[[reformism]]”. Not the least important aspect of the [[Austromarxism]] espoused by Adler, [[Otto Bauer]] and [[Rudolf Hilferding]] was its relevance to the discussions on the left wing of German Social Democracy before 1933.

Vienna 1910 * ''Wegweiser. Studien zur Geistesgeschichte des Sozialismus''. Stuttgart: Dietz 1914 * ''Festschrift für [[Wilhelm Jerusalem]] zu seinem 60. Geburtstag.'' {{For|the artist|Mircea Florian (musician)}} '''Mircea Florian''' ({{IPA-ro|ˈmirt͡ʃe̯a floriˈan|lang}}; April 1, 1888 – October 31, 1960) was a [[Romania]]n philosopher and translator. Active mainly during the [[interwar period]], he was noted as one of the leading proponents of [[rationalism]], opposing it to the ''[[Trăirism|Trăirist]]'' philosophy of [[Nae Ionescu]]. His work, comprising some 20 books, shows Florian as a disciple of [[Centrism|centrists]] and rationalists such as [[Constantin Rădulescu-Motru]] and [[Titu Maiorescu]].
Active in independent [[Social democracy|social democratic]] politics, the philosopher became a political prisoner under the [[Communist Romania|communist regime]]. It was during his time in jail that Florian conceived his philosophical system, published after his death in the treatise ''Recesivitatea ca structură a lumii'' ("Recessivity as World Structure"). In 1990, he was made a posthumous [[list of members of the Romanian Academy|member of the Romanian Academy]].
==Biography== Born in [[Bucharest]], Florian graduated from the Faculty of Letters and Philosophy at the [[University of Bucharest|local university]], where he became a disciple of Rădulescu-Motru and [[P. P. Negulescu]].<ref name="ogenedrept">{{ro icon}} Oana-Georgiana Enăchescu, [http://www.romlit.ro/mircea_florian_-_nedreptatea_unui_destin "Mircea Florian - nedreptatea unui destin"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 13/2002</ref> He afterward took his [[Ph.D.]] at the [[University of Greifswald]], in the [[German Empire]], with a thesis on [[Henri Bergson]]'s notion of time.<ref name="ogenedrept"/> In later years, he found employment as a Bucharest University assistant and substitute professor, lecturing in the History of Philosophy. He was a [[Docent]] from 1916.<ref name="lb(10)350">Boia (2010), p.350</ref>
During [[World War I]], Florian served in the [[Romanian Land Forces]] and was taken prisoner by the [[German Empire|Germans]]. He was transported to an internment camp at [[Krefeld]], alongside figures such as [[Alexandru D. Strurdza]] and [[Ilie Moscovici]].<ref>{{ro icon}} Constantin C. Gomboș, [http://www.historia.ro/exclusiv_web/general/articol/insemnari-prizonieratul-german "Însemnări din prizonieratul german"], in ''Historia'', May 2006</ref> Eventually, Florian was freed by his captors and allowed to lecture at [[Fundațiile Regale|King Carol Foundation]] in Bucharest, under a [[Romania in World War I|German occupation government]]. As Florian later indicated, this was made possible by the intercession of a [[Germanophile]] scholar, [[Alexandru Tzigara-Samurcaș]], who vouched for him, and by the protection of [[Constantin Giurescu]].<ref name="lb(10)350"/> Following the [[First Armistice at Compiègne|November Armistice]], which reinstated the pro-[[Allies of World War I|Allied]] government, Florian, Tzigara-Samurcaș and Rădulescu-Motru were all subject to an official inquiry, and accused of being [[Collaborationism|collaborators]]. The University Commissions created for this task were largely ineffective, and, among the incriminated, Florian was one of few who presented himself for questioning.<ref>Boia (2010), p.347-356</ref>
In the wake of the war, Florian was in contact with ''[[Ideea Europeană]]'', Rădulescu-Motru's magazine, and went on its conference tour, alongside in various cities by, among others, Nae Ionescu, [[Cora Irineu]], [[Octav Onicescu]], [[Virgil Bărbat]], and [[Emanoil Bucuța]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Gheorghe Grigurcu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/memoriile_unui_hedonist "Memoriile unui hedonist"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 41/2000</ref> However, in later years, he remained largely cut off from his public: said to have been shy in delivering his lectures, he led a private life, and dedicated himself, almost entirely, to research.<ref name="ogenedrept"/>
He wrote a large body of works over a short time, including such titles as: ''Îndrumare în filosofie'' ("Philosophical Companion"), ''Rostul și utilitatea filosofiei'' ("The Purpose and Use of Philosophy"), ''Știință și raționalism'' ("Science and Rationalism"), ''Cosmologia elenă'' ("Hellenic Cosmology"), ''Antinomiile credinței'' ("The [[Antinomy|Antinomies]] of Faith"), ''Kant și criticismul până la Fichte'' ("[[Immanuel Kant|Kant]] and the Critical Method before [[Johann Gottlieb Fichte|Fichte]]"), ''Cunoaștere și existență'' ("Knowledge and Being"), ''Reconstrucție filosofică'' ("Philosophical Reconstruction"), ''Metafizică și artă'' ("Metaphysics and Art"), ''Misticism și credință'' ("Mysticism and Faith").<ref name="ogenedrept"/> Although absorbed by his academic work, Florian affiliated with social democracy, and was a member of the [[Romanian Social Democratic Party (1927-1948)|Social Democratic Party]], the [[Constantin Titel Petrescu]] wing.<ref name="ogenedrept"/>
Florian's philosophy developed from ideas common to both Rădulescu-Motru and the 19th-century thinker [[Titu Maiorescu]], herald of Romania's moderate and critical approach to philosophy. Florian is therefore ranked among the third-generation "Maiorescans", and seen as reactivating the spirit of Maiorescu's literary club ''[[Junimea]]''.<ref name="ogenedrept"/><ref name="zopasionanta">{{ro icon}} [[Z. Ornea]], [http://www.romlit.ro/o_pasionant_carte_de_filosofie "O pasionantă carte de filosofie"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 17/1999</ref> After [[World War I]], the ''Junimist'' legacy came in direct contradiction with Nae Ionescu's critique of rationalism, which was growing in popularity and lending its support to the [[far right]]'s causes.<ref name="ogenedrept"/> Florian's steady opposition to Ionescu, in both concept and method, has been described as the "dualism" of interwar [[Romanian philosophy]].<ref name="ogenedrept"/>
By the time of [[World War II]], Mircea Florian was still pursuing a debate with the two schools of irrationalism, promoted by [[Lucian Blaga]] and [[Constantin Noica]]. Granted a full professorship in 1940, he was presented for Romanian Academy membership by his mentor Rădulescu-Motru, but the proposal failed to gather support.<ref name="ogenedrept"/> Blaga gave poor reviews to his work in ''Saeculum'' magazine, and, in one (disputed) interpretation, may have portrayed him as the unknown adversary in the virulent lampoon ''Săpunul filozofic'' ("Philosophic Soap", 1943).<ref>{{ro icon}} Florian Roatiș, [http://www.romlit.ro/despre_polemica_blaga-motru "Despre polemica Blaga-Motru"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 4/2009</ref> According to literary historian [[Z. Ornea]], Florian's relative lack of exposure is unfair, since his works may rank better than those of either Noica or Blaga.<ref name="zopasionanta"/> Florian was also an adversary of official [[fascism]], before and during the [[Ion Antonescu]] dictatorship. Like [[Grigore T. Popa]], [[Constantin I. Parhon]], [[Alexandru Rosetti]], [[Mihai Ralea]], and several other academics, he was in contact with the underground [[Romanian Communist Party]] and the [[Union of Patriots (Romania)|Union of Patriots]], and, as such, kept under close surveillance by the ''[[Siguranța Statului]]'' agents.<ref>Boia (2012), p.236-237</ref>
Florian's stance, and especially his commitment to independent social democracy, made him a suspect upon the establishment of Romania's communist regime. As noted by researcher Victor Frunză, Florian and [[Alexandru Claudian]] made a "high sacrifice" when they refused to give in to "blackmail" and would not join the "Workers' Party" (as the Communist Party styled itself upon its absorption of Social Democratic sympathizers).<ref>Victor Frunză, ''Istoria stalinismului în România'', [[Humanitas publishing house|Humanitas]], Bucharest, 1990, p.274. {{ISBN|973-28-0177-8}}</ref> In 1948, he was stripped of his university chair.<ref name="ogenedrept"/><ref>Boia (2012), p.302</ref> Placed under constant surveillance by the [[Securitate]], Romania's new secret police, he was soon after arrested. During his eight-month-long imprisonment without trial, he had the revelation on "recessivity as world structure".<ref name="ogenedrept"/> The new system evidenced that Florian had come to criticize some of the basic assumptions in [[Western philosophy]], and conceiving of the world through the teachings of [[genetics]].<ref name="ogenedrept"/> His system divided existence alongside its two, equal but alternating, attributes: the [[Dominance (genetics)|dominant]] trait tempered by the recessive (albeit not degraded) one; violence to love, rational to irrational, [[nationalism]] to [[supranationalism]].<ref name="ogenedrept"/>
The imprisonment is said to have been a grueling experience: allegedly, his wife Angela no longer recognized him upon his return to the family home.<ref name="ogenedrept"/> A while after, Florian was partly reintegrated into academia, and assigned a researcher's position at the Institute of Philosophy. There, he dedicated himself to translating [[Aristotle]]'s ''[[Organon]]'', while in committing his ''Recesivitatea'' to paper in his spare time.<ref name="ogenedrept"/>
''Recesivitatea'' was only published 23 years after Florian's death, with [[Editura Eminescu]]. Reportedly, the text had suffered cuts and interventions by [[Censorship in Communist Romania|communist censors]].<ref name="ogenedrept"/> Florian's role was reconsidered mainly after the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989]], when he was made a posthumous member of the Academy.<ref name="ogenedrept"/> His full work was recovered for the public and reviewed by philosopher [[Mircea Flonta]], in a 1998 volume of essays.<ref name="zopasionanta"/>
